Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: The acquaintance's car has broken down on a quiet road, and they are calling for assistance.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Story:
The phone buzzed just as I was dialing another number from my call list. I glanced at the screen—Sam, an old friend from college. I hesitated, but answered. His voice was shaky; his car had broken down on a deserted road, and he needed someone to come get him. I could hear the worry in his voice, and I knew he wouldn’t have called unless he was desperate. My instinct was to grab my keys and go, to be the friend he needed right now.

But then I looked at the clock. Only an hour left in my shift, and I was still three sales short of my weekly target. If I didn’t make it, my manager would be on my case again, and my bonus would slip away. I could almost hear her voice reminding me how important these last calls were. My headset felt heavier, the office air staler. I wanted to help Sam, but I also needed this job. My mind raced, torn between the friend who needed me and the numbers I needed to hit.
